TEXT.English: [TAB]Some call him The Laughing Man, or the Momus, or the Jack of Tears. Whatever he's called, the King of the Balseraphs has held court at the dark heart of Jubilee for at least two centuries, and there is evidence he occupied this land before the Age of Ice, though perhaps in a different form. He has since grown mighty on the power of the blood of captured slaves.[PARAGRAPH:1]Yet the Laughing Man is not a mere menace to be feared and destroyed. Mad, capricious, and deadly being that he is, he also possesses a certain gallows humor, a fondness for bravery and honesty, and a seemingly insuperable compulsion to keep his word (though he is fond of using tricks and the subtleties of language to keep from being locked into any agreements).[PARAGRAPH:2]All alone. Just him and four walls. Again.[PARAGRAPH:1]"You know you weren't in jail back then, dear boy," Sister Serisa told him. "The Sisterhood of Sirona took care of you, as best we could. The Asylum was unpleasant, perhaps, but it wasn't like this. You were starving when we took you in, starving and wandering the street conversing with your long dead parents."[PARAGRAPH:1]"She tried to keep us away from you, Perpentach. Locked us all away, told you we wouldn't always be there with you." His mother reached out her arms to him.[PARAGRAPH:1]"You aren't mad, child," Kylorin, his savior, told him. "You're a magical savant, a person with exceptional talent. Talent for mind magic in your case. The Asylum was proof of that. Almost three hundred patients were dead of neglect, because the entire sisterhood is enthralled by your every whim. I could use power like that."[PARAGRAPH:1]His teacher paced the small cell. "Magic always has an effect on those who use it, I've found, especially the unprepared. Your power brought a terrible price upon you-a copy of those in whose heads you trespassed, residing in your own mind. This was the source of your madness. When I found you, I locked this part of your mind away using your own power."[PARAGRAPH:1]"That's not all you did," said the older Kylorin to his young apparition. "You traded madness for wickedness. We were too power-mad to notice how corrupted you were, my son. I'm sorry I had to do this to you."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Corrupted? You betrayed us, and everything we worked for!" The younger Kylorin pushed the elder against the cold stone wall of Perpentach's cell. "I would have been proud of what Perpentach was able to accomplish!"[PARAGRAPH:1]"Proud? Gods, I killed Gastrius for less than the atrocity Perpentach committed."[PARAGRAPH:1]Gastrius leaned in over his mentor's shoulder to add, "But you couldn't kill Perp. He was stronger than you, the strongest of us all. He almost killed you, the great and powerful Kylorin-self-righteous traitor."[PARAGRAPH:1]The elder Kylorin pushed free, turned away from the crowd. "The evil he did... it wasn't his fault though, it was ours. But I had to stop him. So I let us out. His greatest weakness, at a critical moment, when he nearly overcame me, I undid the protection I had once applied, and that rush of madness was enough. And now we're in here, alone with you. Maybe I should end your sad life once and for all."[PARAGRAPH:1]"You stay back!" shouted his mother.[PARAGRAPH:2]Perpentach found being alone with his thoughts too crowded. He fell to the floor, covering his ears and screaming in an attempt to find peace. It was in vain, and desperately he set out his mind in search of others, of some firmament in the sea of his madness. Kylorin had not made the mistake of underestimating him again-there were no human settlements for many miles of his prison, a sunken tower deep in swampland. Every night he searched for any thought, any glimmer of sentient life, until he passed out.[PARAGRAPH:1]"I swear, you'll drag us to the ends of Patria before you find Kurias, Balmaflu." The speaker was just at the edge of Perpentach's perception, and moving away. A glimmer of hope alit in Perpentach's mind, a wild plan. As he felt the travelers slipping away, he jumped over to this man's mind. His connection to his own body wavered, almost completely broken; back in the cell the mage collapsed to the ground.[PARAGRAPH:1]"I hear the river," Balmaflu replied, "I'm sure it runs west-Momus, are you alright?" The leader of their troupe leader had gone pale, stopping his wagon abruptly.[PARAGRAPH:1]"I-we must return..." The Momus was filled with a great unease. Perpentach was desperate to return to his body; hiding in another's mind he was cut off from most of his power. But he needed more than this small theatre troupe to overcome the mindless golems between him and freedom. So he would bide his time... let these fools lead him to a town.[PARAGRAPH:1]The Momus shook his head. "I'm sorry, my friend... for a moment my thoughts were not my own, as they say. But let us hurry, this marsh gives me ill-feelings."[PARAGRAPH:2]Rork sought his daughter. She should have returned with the milking. He found her in the field, being dragged away by wolf. Rork grabbed a pitchfork and chased after the wolf. It stayed just out of reach, but he wouldn't give up the chase if it cost him his life, so dear was his daughter.[PARAGRAPH:1]So hated was the constable's cousin. So beautiful was the blacksmith's love. So valuable was the goods stolen from the mayor's son.[PARAGRAPH:1]By the time the performers were in sight of the village, they could see the mob marching their way, each person chasing its own demon. The Momus was nearly passed out due to all the energy Perpentach had drained from him to power his illusions. He managed to rasp out "Follow the crowd... back to the swamp..."[PARAGRAPH:2]Many of the villages fell to the assault on the golems. Many had fallen along the way, incapable of the three day march back to the prison. In the end enough survived to free Perpentach. None were forgotten, however. A great multitude joined the crowd inside his mind, but Perpentach learned there were more ways to survive madness than hiding from it. He embraced it, mastering the minds within his mind, ruling both a small fiefdom far from Kylorin's fire, and a grand multitude in the courts inside his mind.
TEXT.French: Certains l'appellent Le Rieur, le Momos, ou le Valet des Larmes. Qu'importe son nom, le Roi des Balséraphs a été à la tête de sa cour dans les noires profondeurs du Jubilé depuis au moins deux siècles, et il existe des preuves de sa présence sur ces terres avant l'Âge de Glace, bien que peut-être sous une forme différente. Il est depuis devenu puissant grâce au sang des esclaves capturés.[PARAGRAPH:1]Pourtant le Rieur n'est pas une simple menace à caindre et détruire. Aussi fou, capricieux et mortel qu'il soit, il possède également une dose d'humour morbide, un pencahnt pour la bravoure et l'honnêteté, et visiblement une volonté à toute épreuve de tenir ses promesses (même s'il aime à utiliser des astuces et des subtilités du langage pour ne pas se retrouver coincé par un accord).[PARAGRAPH:2]Tout seul. Juste lui et quatre murs. Encore.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Tu sais que tu n'étais pas en prison à cette époque, cher enfant," lui dit Sœur Serisa. "La sororité de Sirona a pris soin de toi du mieux qu'elle a pu. L'Asile était peut-être déplaisant, mais il n'en était pas une. Tu mourais de faim quand nous t'avons recueilli, mourant de faim et errant dans les rues tout en conversant avec tes parents morts depuis longtemps."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Elle a essayé de nous éloigner de toi, Perpentach. De nous enfermer au loin, de te dire que nous ne serions pas toujours là pour toi." Sa mère tendit les bras vers lui.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Tu n'es pas fou, mon enfant", lui dit Kylorin, son sauveur. "Tu as un don pour la magie, une personne avec un talent exceptionnel. Un don pour la magie des pensées en l'occurence. L'Asile en a été la preuve. Pratiquement trois cents patients sont décédés de négligence tandis que la sororité entière était à l'écoute du moindre de tes caprices. Je pourrais utiliser un tel pouvoir."[PARAGRAPH:1]Son professeur arpentait la petite cellule. "La magie a toujours un effet sur ceux qui l'utilisent, ai-je découvert, et en particulier ceux qui n'y sont pas préparés. Ton pouvoir s'accompagne d'un terrible fardeau, une copie de ceux dont tu as forcé l'esprit, résidant dans ton esprit. C'était la source de ta folie. Quand je t'ai trouvé, j'ai scellé à part cette portion de ton esprit en utilisant mes pouvoirs."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Ce n'est pas tout ce que tu as fait," dit le vieux Kylorin à sa jeune apparition. "Tu as échangé la folie avec la méchanté. Nous étions trop ivres de pouvoir pour voir à quel point tu étais corrompu mon enfant. Je suis désolé d'avoir dû te faire subir tous ça."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Corrompu ? Tu nous as trahis, et tout ce pour quoi nous avions œuvré !" Le jeune Kylorin poussa le vieux contre le mur de pierre froide de la cellule de Perpentach. "J'aurais été fier de ce que Perpentach aurait été capable d'accomplir !"[PARAGRAPH:1]"Fier ? Bon dieu, j'ai tué Gastrius pour moins d'atrocités que celles commises par Perpentach."[PARAGRAPH:1]Gasrtius s'appuya sur l'épaule de son mentor pour ajouter, "mais tu n'as pas pu tuer Perp. Il était plus puissant que toi, plus puissant que n'importe lequel d'enter nous. Il a failli te tuer, toi le grand et puissant Kylorin, traitre juste."[PARAGRAPH:1]Le vieux Kylorin se libéra et tourna le dos aux autres. "Il répandit le mal... mais ce n'était pourtant pas sa faute, mais la nôtre. Mais je devais l'arrêter. Je nous ai donc libérés. Sa plus grande faiblesse, à un moment critique, quand il m'a pratiquement surpassé, j'ai ôté la protection que j'avais mise en place, et ce torrent de folie était suffisant. Et maintenant nous somme là, seuls avec toi. Peut-être devrais-tu mettre fin à tes tristes jours une fois pour toutes."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Reculez !" cria sa mère.[PARAGRAPH:2]Perpentach fut trouvé seul dans ses pensées surpeuplées. Il tomba au sol, se bouchant les oreilles et hurlant dans l'espoir de trouver la paix. Mais en vain. Et, en désespoir de cause, il étendit son esprit à la recherche d'autres, comme une ile dans son océan de folie. Kylorin n'avait pas refait l'erreur de le sous-estimer, et il n'y avait aucune habitation humain à plusieurs kilomètres autour de sa prison, une tour perdu dans les profondeurs des marécages. Chaque nuit il cherchait une pensée, une étincelle de vie consciente, jusqu'à l'inconscience.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Je t'assure, tu nous conduiras aux confins de Patria avant qu'on trouve Kurias, Balmaflu." L'interlocuteur était aux bords de la perception de Perpentach, et s'éloignait. Une étincelle d'espoir s'alluma dans l'esprit de Perpentach, qui imagina un plan fou. Tandis qu'il sentait les voyageurs lui échapper, il s'engouffra dans l'esprit de l'homme. Sa connection avec son propre corps faiblit, pratiquement rompue. Dans sa cellule, le corps du mage s'effondra.[PARAGRAPH:1]"J'entend la rivière," répondit Balmaflu, "je suis sûr qu'elle coule vers l'Ouest. Momos, tu te sens bien ?" Le chef de leur troupe était devenu livide, arrêtant brutalement son wagon. [PARAGRAPH:1]J'ai... On doit revenir sur nos pas..." Le Momos avait un fort sentiment de malaise. Perpentach était désespéré d'être dans ce corps. En se cachant dans l'esprit d'un autre il était privé de la majeure partie de son pouvoir. Mais il avait besoin de plus que cette petite troupe de théâtre pour venir à bout des golems sans âme se trouvant entre lui et sa liberté. Il attendrait donc son heure... et laisserait ces sots le mener à une ville.[PARAGRAPH:1]Le Momos secoua la tête. "Désolé, mon ami... pendant un moment je n'étais plus moi-même, comme ils disent. Mais dépêchons-nous, ce marais me met mal à l'aise."[PARAGRAPH:2]Rork chercha sa fille. Elle devrait être de retour avec la traite. Il la trouva dans les champs, emmenée de force par un loup. Rork se saisit d'une fourche et partit en chasse du loup. Il restait juste hors de portée, mais il n'abandonnerait pas la traque, au péril de sa vie. Sa fille comptait à ce point pour lui.[PARAGRAPH:1] Le cousin policier était haïssable à ce point. De même qu'était beau l'amour du forgeron. Ou de valeurs étaint les biens volés au fils du maire.[PARAGRAPH:1]Quand les acteurs furent en vue du village, ils virent l'attroupement marcher dans leur direction, chacun chassant son propre démon. Le Momos était pratiquement évanoui à cause de toute l'énergie que lui drainait Perpentach pour alimenter ses illusions. Il parvint à articuler "Suivez la foule... retournons au marais..."[PARAGRAPH:2]De nombreux villageois moururent lors de l'assaut sur les golems. Beaucoup s'effondrèrent au bord de la route, incapables de survivre aux trois jours de marche pour revenir à la prison. Au final, ils furent suffisamment nombreux pour libérer Perpentach. Cependant, aucun ne fut oublié. Une multitude se joignit à la foule dans son esprit, mais Perpentach avait appris qu'il y avait d'auters moyens de survivre à la folie que de s'en cacher. Il l'accueillit, maîtrisant les esprits contenus dans le sien, régnant à la fois sur un petit fief loin du regard de Kylorin et une grande multitude dans la cour de son esprit.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Manche nennen ihn den Lachenden Mann, den Momus oder den Tränennarr. Wie auch immer er genannt wird, der König der Balseraph hält er schon seit mindestens zwei Jahrhundertenden den Thron im dunklen Herzen Jubilees und es gibt Hinweise, dass er dieses Land schon vor dem Zeitalter des Eises bewohnte, wenn vielleicht auch in einer anderen Gestalt als heute. Seitdem wurde er durch die Kraft des Blutes gefangener Sklaven zunehmend mächtiger.[PARAGRAPH:1]Dennoch ist der Lachende Mann keine bloße Gefahr, die gefürchtet und vernichtet werden muss. So wahnsinnig, wankelmütig und tödlich er auch sein mag, besitzt er doch eine Art Galgenhumor, eine Vorliebe für Tapfer- und Ehrlichkeit, sowie einen scheinbar unüberwindlichen Zwang sein Wort niemals zu brechen (wobei er sich darauf versteht sich durch Schliche und Wortgewandtheit einem das Wort im Mund zu verdrehen, so dass er sich nie festlegen muss).[PARAGRAPH:2]Ganz alleine. Nur er und vier kalte Steinwände. Schon wieder.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Du weißt, du warst damals nicht in einem Kerker, mein Junge," erklärte ihm Schwester Serisa. "Die Schwesternschaft Sironas pflegte dich, so gut wir konnten. Das Irrenhaus war vielleicht unangenehm, aber es war kein Kerker. Du warst am Verhungern, als wir dich aufnahmen, wanderste hungernd durch die Straßen, nur mit deinen toten Eltern redend."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Sie versuchte dich von uns fernzuhalten, Perpentach. Sie schlossen uns alle weg, erzählten dir, wir würden nicht immer bei dir sein." Seine Mutter streckte ihre Arme nach ihm aus.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Du bist nicht verrückt, mein Kind," erzählte sein Retter ihm sein Retter, Kylorin. "Du bist ein magisches Wunderkind, eine Person mit einem außerordentlichen Begabung. Eine Begabung für Geistesmagie in deinem Falle. Das Irrenhaus war der Beweis. Fast dreihundert Patienten starben durch Vernachlässigung, nur weil die gesamte Schwesterschaft in deinen Bann gezogen war, von jeder deiner Launen. Ich hätte solch eine Macht brauchen können."[PARAGRAPH:1]Sein Mentor schritt durch die enge Zelle. "Magie hat immer einen Effekt auf den, der sie nutzt, habe ich herausgefunden, besonders auf die Ungeschulten und Unvorbereiteten. Für deine Macht hast du einen furchtbaren Preis gezahlt - Abbilder all jener Geister, in die du eindrangest, wohnen nun in deinem Geiste. Dies ist die Ursache deines Wahnsinns. Als ich dich fand, versperrte ich diesen Teil deines Geistes, kraft deiner eigenen Fähigkeit."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Das ist nicht alles, was du getan hast," sagte der ältere Kylorin zu seiner jungen Erscheinung. "Du hast Wahnsinn gegen Boshaftigkeit getauscht. Wir waren zu machtbessessen, um zu bemerken, wie verdorben du warst, mein Sohn. Es tut mir leid, dass ich dir das antun musste."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Verdorben? Du hast uns verraten und alles wofür wir uns mühten!" Der jüngere Kylorin stieß den älteren gegen die kalte Steinwand der Zelle Perpentachs. "Ich wäre stolz auf das, was Perpentach erreicht hat!"[PARAGRAPH:1]"Stolz? Bei den Göttern, ich habe Gastrius für weniger getötet, als die Grausamkeiten, die Perpentach beging."[PARAGRAPH:1]Gastrius lehnte sich über die Schulter seines Mentors, "Aber du konntest Perp nicht töten. Er war stärker als du, der Stärkste von uns allen. Er tötete dich beinahe, den großen, mächtigen Kylorin, den selbstgerechten Verräter."[PARAGRAPH:1]Der ältere Kylorin befreite sich und wandte sich vom Pulk ab. "Die Untaten, die er beging... es war nicht sein, sondern unser Fehler. Aber ich musste ihn aufhalten, darum lies ich uns frei. Seine größte Schwäche, während eines kritischen Augenblicks! Als er mich beinahe besiegte, brach der Schutz, den ich einst schuf und der einsetzende Wahnsinn war genug. Und nun sind wir hier, allein mit dir. Vielleicht sollte ich dein trauriges Leben ein für alle Mal beenden."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Bleib zurück!" schrie seine Mutter.[PARAGRAPH:2]Mit seinen Gedanken so ganz allein, wurde es Perpentach zu viel. Er fiel gen Boden, seine Ohren bedeckend, schreiend und keifend, in der Hoffnung Ruhe zu finden. Es war vergebens und verzweifelt sandte er seinen Geist aus, auf der Suche nach anderen Gedanken, einem Firmament am Rande der See seines Irrwitzes. Kylorin machte nicht erneut den Fehler ihn zu unterschätzen - es gab im Umkreis von vielen Meilen um sein Gefängnis, einem versunkenen Turm im Sumpfland, keine einzige Menschenseele. Jede Nacht suchte er nach fremden Gedanken, dem Schimmer eines Bewusstseins, bis er ohnmächtig wurde.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Ich schwöre, du wirst uns zu den Enden des Vaterlands zerren, bevor du Kurias findest, Balmaflu." Der Redende war am Rande der magischen Wahrnehmung Perpentachs und entfernte sich langsam. Ein Funke der Hoffnung entflammte in Perpentachs Hirn, ein waghalsiger Plan. Als er spürte, wie die Reisenden ihm entwichen, sprang er in den Geist dieses Mannes. Die Verbindung zu seinen eigenen Körper schwankte, war fast durchtrennt - in der Zelle brach der Magier kraftlos zusammen.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Ich höre den Fluss," antwortete Balmaflu, "ich bin mir sicher, dass er westlich von Momos läuft - bist du in Ordnung?" Der Anführer ihrer Schauspieltruppe wurde blass und hielt den Wagen abrupt an.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Ich - wir müssen zurückkehren..." Der Momus wurde mit großer Unruhe erfüllt. Perpentach wollte verzweifelt zu seinen Körper zurück; sich in einem fremden Geiste zu verstecken, beraubte ihn eines Großteil seiner Kräfte. Aber er brauchte mehr als diese kleine Theatertruppe, um die geistlosen Golems zu besiegen, die zwischen ihm und seiner Freiheit standen. So musste er den rechten Augenblick abwarten... sich von diesen Narren in ein Dorf führen zu lassen.[PARAGRAPH:1]Der Momus schüttelte seinen Kopf. "Entschuldigt, mein Freund, für einen Augenblick, waren meine Gedanken wo anders, wie man so schön sagt. Aber lasst uns eilen, ich kriege ein ungutes Gefühl in diesen Marschen.[PARAGRAPH:2]Rork suchte nach seiner Tochter. Sie sollte längst mit der Milch zurück sein. Er fand sie im Feld, weggezerrt von einem Wolf. Rork griff zu seiner Mistgabel und jagte dem Wolf hinterher. Er bleib außer Reichweite, aber er würde nicht aufgeben, selbst wenn es sein Leben kosten sollte, so lieb war ihm seine Tochter.[PARAGRAPH:1]So verhasst war der Cousin des Wachmanns. So wunderschön war des Schmiedes Liebchen. So wertvoll waren die gestohlenen Güter des Bürgermeisterssohns.[PARAGRAPH:1]Nach einiger Zeit waren die Schauspieler in Sichtweite eines Dorfs. Sie sahen einen Mob, der sich den Weg bahnte, jeder seinen eigenen Dämon hinterherjagend. Der Momus wurde ohnmächtig, nachdem Perpentach ihm so viel Kraft entzog um seine Trugbilder zu schaffen. Er röchelte noch: "Folgt der Menge... zurück zum Sumpf..."[PARAGRAPH:2]Viele Dorfbewohner fielen beim Angriff auf die Golems. Viele fielen aber schon zuvor, waren sie doch zu schwach für den Dreitagesmarsch zum Gefängnis, aber genug überlebten, um Perpentach zu befreien. Keiner wurde jedoch jemals vergessen. Eine große Schar neuer Bewohner zog in Perpentachs Geist, aber er lernte bald neue Wege, wie er mit seinem Wahn leben konnte. Er gab sich dem Irrsinn hin, meisterte die Geister in seinem Geiste und herrschte sowohl über ein Lehen weit entfernt von den Flammen Kylorins, als auch über eine Heerschar in seinem Geiste.
TEXT.Italian: Alcuni lo chiamano L'Uomo che Ride, o il Momus, o il Fante delle Lacrime. In qualunque modo venga chiamato, il Re dei Balseraph ha mantenuto la sua corte nell'oscuro cuore di Jubilee per almeno due secoli, e ci sono le prove del fatto che governava quelle terre anche prima dell'Era del Ghiaccio, anche se forse in un modo diverso. Da allora è diventato potente grazie al sangue versato dagli schiavi catturati.[PARAGRAPH:1]Eppure l'Uomo che Ride non è una semplice minaccia da temere e distruggere. Pazzo, capriccioso, e letale essendo quello che è, possiede anche un umorismo da patibolo, una predilezione per il coraggio e l'onesta, e una compulsione apparentemente insuperabile a mantenere la parola data (sebbene ama usare trucchetti e le sottigliezze della lingua per evitare di essere legato a qualsiasi accordo).[PARAGRAPH:2]Tutto solo. Solo lui e le quattro mura. Di nuovo.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Sai che allora non eri in prigione, caro ragazzo" Sorella Serisa gli disse. "La Sorellanza di Sirona si prendeva cura di te, al meglio delle nostre capacità. Il Manicomio era spiacevole, forse, ma non era come questo. Stavi morendo di fame quando ti abbiamo accolto, e giravi senza meta per le strade conversando con i tuoi genitori deceduti da molto tempo".[PARAGRAPH:1]"Cercava di tenerci lontano da te, Perpentach. Ci ha rinchiuso tutti, dicendoti che non saremmo mai stati più li con te". Sua madre allungò le braccia verso di lui.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Non sei pazzo, ragazzo," Kylorin, il suo salvatore, gli disse. "Tu sei portato per la magia, una persona con un talento eccezionale. Un talento per la magia della mente nel tuo caso. Il Manicomio era la prova di ciò. Circa trecento pazienti erano morti per negligenza, perché l'intera sorellanza era affascinata da ogni tuo capriccio. Io potrei fare uso di un tale potere".[PARAGRAPH:1]Il suo insegnante camminò nella piccola stanza. "Ho scoperto che la magia ha sempre un'influenza su coloro che la usano, soprattutto sugli impreparati. Il tuo potere porta con se un prezzo terribile, una copia di coloro nella cui testa sei passato rimane nella tua. Questa è la fonte della tua pazzia. Quando ti ho trovato, ho messo da parte quella zona della tua mente usando il tuo stesso potere".[PARAGRAPH:1]"Non hai fatto solo questo," disse il Kylorin anziano alla sua apparizione più giovane. "Hai scambiato la pazzia per la depravazione. Eravamo troppo ebbri di potere per notare quanto corrotto tu fossi, figlio mio. Mi dispiace aver dovuto farti questo".[PARAGRAPH:1]"Corrotto? Tu ci hai tradito, insieme a tutto cio per cui abbiamo lavorato!" Il giovane Kylorin spinse quello anziano contro il freddo muro di pietra della cella di Perpentach. "Io sarei stato fiero di ciò che Perpentach era capace di fare!"[PARAGRAPH:1]"Fiero? Dei, ho ucciso Gastrius per atrocità minori di quelle commesse da Perpentach".[PARAGRAPH:1]Gastrius si sporse dalla spalla del suo mentore per aggiungere, "Ma non sei riuscito ad uccidere Perp. Lui era più forte di te, il più forte di tutti noi. Ti ha quasi ucciso, il grande e potente Kylorin il presuntuoso traditore".[PARAGRAPH:1]Il Kylorin anziano non venendo più spinto, si voltò dando le spalle alla folla. "Il male che ha fatto... non era colpa sua, ma nostra. Dovevo comunque fermarlo. Cosi ci ho liberato. La sua più grande debolezza, in un momento critico, quando stava per sopraffarmi, disfai la protezione che avevo fatto, e quella scarica di follia fu sufficente. E ora noi siamo qui, da soli con te. Forse dovrei terminare la tua triste vita una volta per tutte."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Tu stagli lontano!" urlò sua madre.[PARAGRAPH:2]Perpentach trovò i suoi pensieri un pò troppo affollati. Caddè sul pavimento, coprendosi le orecchie e urlando cercando di trovare pace. Era inutile, e in preda alla disperazione usò la sua mente per cercare altri, un qualche rifugio in quel mare di pazzia. Kylorin non aveva commesso di nuovo l'errore di sottovvalutarlo, non c'era alcun insediamento umano per chilometri attorno alla sua prigione, una torre sommersa al centro di paludi. Ogni notte cercò un qualsiasi pensiero, qualsiasi barlume di vita senziente, fino a quando non sveniva.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Giuro, ci trascinerai fino ai confini di Patria prima di trovare Kurias, Balmaflu". Chi parlava era al limite della percezione di Perpentach, e si stava allontanando. Un barlume di speranza si accese nella mente di Perpentach, un piano selvaggio. Mentre sentiva il viaggiatore allontanarsi, si trasferì nella mente di quest'uomo. La connessione al suo corpo vacillò, quasi completamente spezzata; nella cella il mago crollò a terra.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Sento il fiume," rispose Balmaflu, "Sono certo che va ad ovest, Momus, va tutto bene?" Il capo della loro compagnia teatrale era diventato pallido, fermando bruscamente il suo carro.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Io-noi dobbiamo tornare..." Il Momus era molto a disagio. Perpentach voleva tornare al suo corpo disperatamente; nascondendosi nella mente di qualcun'altro era separato dalla maggior parte del suo potere. Ma aveva bisogno di più di questa compagnia teatrale per sconfiggere i golem che si frapponevano tra lui e la libertà. Quindi avrebbe atteso il suo momento... che questi sciocchi lo portino in una città.[PARAGRAPH:1]Il Momus scosse la testa. "Scusatemi, amici... per un momento i miei pensieri non erano miei, come si suol dire. Ma affrettiamoci, questa palude mi da i brividi."[PARAGRAPH:2]Rork cercò sua figlia. Sarebbe dovuta tornare con la mungitura. La trovò in un campo, venendo trascinata via da un lupo. Rork afferrò un forcone e inseguì il lupo. Che rimaneva giusto fuori portata, ma non avrebbe rinunciato all'inseguimento neppure se gli fosse costato la vita, essendogli cosi cara la figlia.[PARAGRAPH:1]Il cugino del conestabile era cosi odiato. La compagna del fabbro cosi bella. Cosi di valore i beni rubati dal figlio del sindaco.[PARAGRAPH:1]Quando gli artisti furono in vista del villaggio, poterono vedere la folla camminare verso di loro, con ogni persona che inseguiva il prorpio demone. Il Momus quasi svenne a causa di tutta l'energia che Perpentach aveva drenato da lui per alimentare le illusioni. Riuscì però a gracchiare "Seguite la folla... ritorniamo alla palude..."[PARAGRAPH:2]Molti abitanti del villaggio morirono andando all'attacco dei golem. Molti erano morti lungo la strada, stremati dalla marcia di tre giorni per tornare alla prigione. Alla fine abbastanza sopravvisserò per liberare Perpentach. Nessuno fu dimenticato, però. In tanti si unirono alla folla presente nella sua mente, ma Perpentach imparò che c'erano altri modi per sopravvivere alla pazzia oltre al nascondersi da essa. Accettandola, padroneggiando le menti dentro la sua mente, governando sia un piccolo feudo lontano dal fuoco di Kylorin che un grande numero di personalità nella sua mente.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Some call him The Laughing Man, or the Momus, or the Jack of Tears. Whatever he's called, the King of the Balseraphs has held court at the dark heart of Jubilee for at least two centuries, and there is evidence he occupied this land before the Age of Ice, though perhaps in a different form. He has since grown mighty on the power of the blood of captured slaves.[PARAGRAPH:1]Yet the Laughing Man is not a mere menace to be feared and destroyed. Mad, capricious, and deadly being that he is, he also possesses a certain gallows humor, a fondness for bravery and honesty, and a seemingly insuperable compulsion to keep his word (though he is fond of using tricks and the subtleties of language to keep from being locked into any agreements).[PARAGRAPH:2]All alone. Just him and four walls. Again.[PARAGRAPH:1]"You know you weren't in jail back then, dear boy," Sister Serisa told him. "The Sisterhood of Sirona took care of you, as best we could. The Asylum was unpleasant, perhaps, but it wasn't like this. You were starving when we took you in, starving and wandering the street conversing with your long dead parents."[PARAGRAPH:1]"She tried to keep us away from you, Perpentach. Locked us all away, told you we wouldn't always be there with you." His mother reached out her arms to him.[PARAGRAPH:1]"You aren't mad, child," Kylorin, his savior, told him. "You're a magical savant, a person with exceptional talent. Talent for mind magic in your case. The Asylum was proof of that. Almost three hundred patients were dead of neglect, because the entire sisterhood is enthralled by your every whim. I could use power like that."[PARAGRAPH:1]His teacher paced the small cell. "Magic always has an effect on those who use it, I've found, especially the unprepared. Your power brought a terrible price upon you-a copy of those in whose heads you trespassed, residing in your own mind. This was the source of your madness. When I found you, I locked this part of your mind away using your own power."[PARAGRAPH:1]"That's not all you did," said the older Kylorin to his young apparition. "You traded madness for wickedness. We were too power-mad to notice how corrupted you were, my son. I'm sorry I had to do this to you."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Corrupted? You betrayed us, and everything we worked for!" The younger Kylorin pushed the elder against the cold stone wall of Perpentach's cell. "I would have been proud of what Perpentach was able to accomplish!"[PARAGRAPH:1]"Proud? Gods, I killed Gastrius for less than the atrocity Perpentach committed."[PARAGRAPH:1]Gastrius leaned in over his mentor's shoulder to add, "But you couldn't kill Perp. He was stronger than you, the strongest of us all. He almost killed you, the great and powerful Kylorin-self-righteous traitor."[PARAGRAPH:1]The elder Kylorin pushed free, turned away from the crowd. "The evil he did... it wasn't his fault though, it was ours. But I had to stop him. So I let us out. His greatest weakness, at a critical moment, when he nearly overcame me, I undid the protection I had once applied, and that rush of madness was enough. And now we're in here, alone with you. Maybe I should end your sad life once and for all."[PARAGRAPH:1]"You stay back!" shouted his mother.[PARAGRAPH:2]Perpentach found being alone with his thoughts too crowded. He fell to the floor, covering his ears and screaming in an attempt to find peace. It was in vain, and desperately he set out his mind in search of others, of some firmament in the sea of his madness. Kylorin had not made the mistake of underestimating him again-there were no human settlements for many miles of his prison, a sunken tower deep in swampland. Every night he searched for any thought, any glimmer of sentient life, until he passed out.[PARAGRAPH:1]"I swear, you'll drag us to the ends of Patria before you find Kurias, Balmaflu." The speaker was just at the edge of Perpentach's perception, and moving away. A glimmer of hope alit in Perpentach's mind, a wild plan. As he felt the travelers slipping away, he jumped over to this man's mind. His connection to his own body wavered, almost completely broken; back in the cell the mage collapsed to the ground.[PARAGRAPH:1]"I hear the river," Balmaflu replied, "I'm sure it runs west-Momus, are you alright?" The leader of their troupe leader had gone pale, stopping his wagon abruptly.[PARAGRAPH:1]"I-we must return..." The Momus was filled with a great unease. Perpentach was desperate to return to his body; hiding in another's mind he was cut off from most of his power. But he needed more than this small theatre troupe to overcome the mindless golems between him and freedom. So he would bide his time... let these fools lead him to a town.[PARAGRAPH:1]The Momus shook his head. "I'm sorry, my friend... for a moment my thoughts were not my own, as they say. But let us hurry, this marsh gives me ill-feelings."[PARAGRAPH:2]Rork sought his daughter. She should have returned with the milking. He found her in the field, being dragged away by wolf. Rork grabbed a pitchfork and chased after the wolf. It stayed just out of reach, but he wouldn't give up the chase if it cost him his life, so dear was his daughter.[PARAGRAPH:1]So hated was the constable's cousin. So beautiful was the blacksmith's love. So valuable was the goods stolen from the mayor's son.[PARAGRAPH:1]By the time the performers were in sight of the village, they could see the mob marching their way, each person chasing its own demon. The Momus was nearly passed out due to all the energy Perpentach had drained from him to power his illusions. He managed to rasp out "Follow the crowd... back to the swamp..."[PARAGRAPH:2]Many of the villages fell to the assault on the golems. Many had fallen along the way, incapable of the three day march back to the prison. In the end enough survived to free Perpentach. None were forgotten, however. A great multitude joined the crowd inside his mind, but Perpentach learned there were more ways to survive madness than hiding from it. He embraced it, mastering the minds within his mind, ruling both a small fiefdom far from Kylorin's fire, and a grand multitude in the courts inside his mind.

TEXT.English: [TAB]How had it come to this? One day Essom's village stood on the border of the Elohim lands, adjoining Belseraphs, his people happily tolerating the bizarre antics of the troubadour nation. The next day the village was in Belseraphs territory and his people were slaves. More startling, they accepted it mindlessly, as if it were the most natural transition in the world.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Stand up straight, ye lazy popinjay, he's coming," Faro snarled.[PARAGRAPH:1]Yesterday such a remark would have been accompanied with the sting of the whip, and the river would have run with blood, but, for today at least, the slaves have been given the day off, so that they could form a crowd of grateful faces, all appreciatively welcoming Perpentech, the Blasphemy made Flesh.[PARAGRAPH:1]The clown prince arrived wearing a red suit with black buttons and golden tassels and trim, the kind that adorned doormen on official state occasions. The orchestra began to play the official Belseraphs national anthem, The Dance of the Deer and Duck.[PARAGRAPH:1]"No! No! No! No! No!" Perpentech squawked. "You're doing it all wrong. You on the fiddle, go and play the harp. And you, yes you, with the trumpet and the big nose, fetch the timpani. And tell the choir to swap with the piccolo section, whilst you're at it."[PARAGRAPH:1]Essom watched the havoc as musicians swapped places with one another, desperately trying to locate an instrument with which they might bear at least a passing acquaintance. It occurred to Essom that Perpentech had quite the most ridiculous voice that he had ever heard, a squeaky, reedy thing of no substance. And yet, such was his charisma, no-one ever heard the voice, just the threat behind it.[PARAGRAPH:1]"And a one-two-three, and in your own time."[PARAGRAPH:1]The resulting melange lacked rhythm, melody and talent, but made up for it with an enthusiasm born of fear. As discordant notes slid into one another with all the elegance of a coach crash, Perpentech swayed from side to side, flicking his wrist here and there in time with some overblown bugle cry or inappropriate cymbal clash. The tempo varied wildly, some musicians finishing early, whilst others were drawn into extended solos. A capella competed with soto voce, and the lyrics fared little better; at least half the choristers started by singing last week's National Anthem, Two fiddles and a tug by Solstice Eve.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Excellent! Excellent! Isn't out so much better when you don't play the music laid out for you? Now where are my doves?"[PARAGRAPH:1]"Doves, Sir?" asked Captain Faro[PARAGRAPH:1]"Doves. To announce my presence of course!" Perpentech sighed. "If you want something done, do it yourself." Essom had not seen the prince change his clothing, but now Perpentech was wearing a dark suit with a top hat. With a flourish, the harbinger of chaos swept out his left arm and a swarm of locusts emerged from his fingertips. They clustered together in the form of two doves and then flew into the crowd.[PARAGRAPH:1]"I apologise for the lack of facilities, sir. It shan't happen again." Captain Faro toadied, but Essom had seen that face before. Tomorrow the whip would be twice as harsh.[PARAGRAPH:1]"I say, Captain, do your feet sweat and stink in this heat?"[PARAGRAPH:1]The non-sequitur stunned Faro into stammering affirmative response.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Well we'll have to do something about that." And Perpentech seized a nosegay from the buttonhole of the silk pyjamas that current served as his raiment. Peeling the petals from the rose, he plucked them delicately letting them drift on the breeze.[PARAGRAPH:1]Somewhere in the crowd a voice cried "She Loves Me." With the next petal, "She Loves Me Not." Soon the entire multitude was declaring undying affection and remorseful regret with each petal, until, with the final "She Loves Me Not", the petals danced on the wind to smother the sun and darken the land below.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Now show me the project."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Of course, Sir."[PARAGRAPH:1]"And do stop calling me, Sir. It sounds so formal. From now on you must refer to me the Most Beneficent Augur of Munificence and Virtue."[PARAGRAPH:1]Captain Faro nodded and showed Perpentech the way to the structure. Three pillars stood in the desert, each a monument to the blood and pain of Elohim slaves. Carved marble masonry, engraved with etchings of frogs and toads dying in burning hail, lay discarded at the side, pieces of a jigsaw that don't fit in place.[PARAGRAPH:1]"In fairness, Si... Your most Beneficent Augur of... er... Our architects don't understand how you expect all the stairwells to be going up all the time."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Really." Perpentech, now dressed in a gold robe which covered him from head to foot, stretched out his arms. "We can't have that. After all, I can hardly be expected to have servants living below stairs if I don't have a staircase in the first place. Allow me to demonstrate."[PARAGRAPH:1]As Perpentech dropped his arms, a figure appeared behind them. Or rather three figures, three dwarves standing atop of each other. The one at the bottom had so many sores and boils it was hard to make out his visage. The central one was smothered in lice and flies, whereas the one at the top, who was slightly taller than the others, had a stage dagger plunged firmly in his chest.[PARAGRAPH:1]The dwarves at the top and the bottom of the stack stuck their arms out, bending their elbows and hands to point at right angles. The central dwarf spoke. "My name is Weevil and below me stands Pickle and above me stands Hyde."[PARAGRAPH:1]The tower of dwarves then rotated on the spot, slowly shuffling until they faced the audience once more. Although there had been no apparent change in the tower whilst their back was to the crowd, now the dwarf with the boils occupied the central spot, with the tall dwarf at the bottom and the lice-infested dwarf on the top of the stack.[PARAGRAPH:1]This time, the dwarves at the top and bottom of the stack made surprised faces, eyes wide open, hands covering their mouths in mock-astonishment. The central dwarf spoke once more. "My name is Pickle, below me stands Hyde and above me stands Weevil."[PARAGRAPH:1]The tower rotated once more. When it faced the audience again, the configuration of dwarves had changed. The dwarf with the flies was at the bottom of the stack, the palms of his hands covering his eyes. The central position was occupied by the dwarf with the stage dagger, his hands closed over his ears. At the top was the pockmarked dwarf, a hand cupped across his mouth. The central dwarf spoke again. "And my name is Hyde, below me stands Weevil and above me stands Pickle."[PARAGRAPH:1]"So there you have it," stated Perpentech, as if he had just taught a child how to count to ten "When you build my staircase just remember Weevil, Pickle and Hyde."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Erm... Right" replied Faro. He almost sounded like he believed it.[PARAGRAPH:1]Perpentech clutched his nose, as if to stifle a sneeze. "I do apologise," he squeaked nasally, and then broke wind with aplomb. TEXT.French: Comment en est-on arrivés là ? Un jour le village d'Essom se trouvait aux frontières des territoires Elohims, contigus aux Balséraphs, sa population tolérant joyeusement les bizarres cabrioles de la nation troubadour. Le jour suivant, le village se trouvait en territoire Balséraph et ses habitants étaient des esclaves. Plus surprenant, ils l'acceptèrent sans heurt, comme si c'était là la transition la plus naturelle au monde;[PARAGRAPH:1]"Tenez-vous droits, bande de paresseux prétentieux, Il arrive," rugit Faro.[PARAGRAPH:1]Hier une telle remarque aurait été accompagnée du chant du fouet, et la rivière aurait été rougie de sang, mais, du moins pour aujourd'hui, les esclaves avaient un jour de congé. Ils pouvaient former une foule de visages reconnaissants, tous accueillant avec reconnaissance Perpentach, le Blasphème Incarné.[PARAGRAPH:1]Le Prince Clown arriva, portant un costume rouge avec des boutons noirs et garnis de glands dorés, le genre qui parait les portiers lors de réunions d'état. L'orchestre commença à jouer l'hymne national balséraph, La Danse du Cerf et du CAnard.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Non ! Non ! Non ! Non ! Non !" piailla Perpentach. "Vous ne le jouez pas bien. Vous, au violon, bougez et jouez de la harpe. Et vous, oui vous, avec la trompette et le gros nez, apportez les timbales. Et dites au chœur de changer avec le groupe de joueurs de piccolo, tant que vous y êtes."[PARAGRAPH:1]Essom regardait le désordre tandis que les musiciens échangaient leurs places, tentant désespérément de repérer un instrument avec lequel ils pourraient se débrouiller un minimum. Il apparut à Essom que Perpentach avait en fait la voix la plus ridicule qu'ils avaient jamais entendue, un son grinçant et aigu sans substance. Et pourtant, son charisme était tel que personne n'entendit jamais la vois, mais seulement la menace voilée.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Et un-deux-trois, et à votre rythme."[PARAGRAPH:1]Le résultat était un mélange manquant de rythme, de mélodie et de talent, mais bourré d'un enthousiasme né de la peur. Tandis que les notes discordantes se percutaient avec l'élégance d'un accident de voiture, Perpentach voletait d'un côté à l'autre, balançant son poignet ça et là en rythme avec un cri exagéré de clairon ou une percussion inopportune de cymbale. Le rythme variait fortement, certains musiciens terminant rapidement tandis que d'autres étaient entraînés dans des solos à ralonge. A capella rivalisant avec Soto Voce, et les paroles allèrent un peu mieux; au moins la moitié des choristes commencèrent par chanter le dernier couplet de l'Hymne National, deux violons et une saccade par le Solstice d'Eve.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Excellent ! Excellent ! N'est-ce pas tellement mieux quand vous ne jouez pas la musique qui vous correspond ? Et maintenant, où sont mes colombes ?"[PARAGRAPH:1]"Des colombes, Monseigneur ?" demanda le capitaine Faro.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Des colombes. Pour annoncer ma présence bien sûr !" soupira Perpentach. "Si vous voulez que quelque soit fait, faites le vous-même." Essom n'avait pas vu le Prince changer de tenue, mais Perpentach portait maintenant un costume noir avec un haut-de-forme. D'un geste, le héraut du chaos balaya le bras gauche et un essaim de criquets sortit de ses doigts. Ils s'agglutinèrent en forme de deux colombes et volèrent vers la foule.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Je m'excuse du manque d'infrastructures, sire. Ça n'arrivera plus. Le capitaine Faro flagorna, mais Essom avait déjà vu cette expression auparavant. Demain, le fouet serait deux fois plus rude.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Je demandais, capitaine, est-ce que vos pieds transpirent et puent par cette chaleur ?"[PARAGRAPH:1]L'illogisme assoma Faro dans un bégaiement affirmatif.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Hé bien, nous devons faire quelque chose pour ça." Et Perpentach saisit un petit bouquet de la boutonnière du pyjama en soie qui lui servait de vêtement. Arrachant les pétales de la rose, il les cueillit délicatement, les laissant dériver au vent.[PARAGRAPH:1]Quelque part dans la foule, une voix cria "elle m'aime." Au pétale suivant, "Elle ne m'aime pas." Rapidement, toute la populace déclarait un affection fervente et un regret amer à chaque pétale, jusqu'à, avec le "elle ne m'aime pas" final, ce que les pétales dansent au vent et masquent le soleil et assombrissent le sol en-dessous.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Maintenant, montrez moi le projet."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Avec plaisir, sire."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Et arrêtez de m'appeler sire. Ça semble tellement officiel. Dorénavant, vous devrez vous adresser à moi en m'appelant l'Augure le Plus Bienfaisant de la Munificence et de la Vertu."[PARAGRAPH:1]Le capitaine Faro fit un signe de tête et montra à Perpentach le chemin vers la structure. Trois piliers se dressaient dans le désert, chacun comme un monument au sang et à la douleur des esclaves elohims. Constitué de blocs de marbre taillés dans la masse, décoré d'eaux-fortes de grenouilles et crapauds mourant dans une grêle incandescente, et gisant éparpillé autour, les pièces d'un puzzle qui ne trouvent pas leur place.[PARAGRAPH:1]"En toute honnêteté, si ... votre augure le plus bienfaisant de ... euh ... nos architectes ne comprennent pas pourquoi vous vous attendez à ce que les cages d'escaliers montent tout le temps."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Vraiment." Perpentach, maintenant habillé d'un robe dorée le couvrant de la tête aux pieds tendit les bras. "On ne peut pas obtenir ça. Après tout, je peux difficilement avoir des serviteurs vivant sous les escaliers si je n'ai pas auparavant des cages d'escaliers. Permettez-moi de vous montrer."[PARAGRAPH:1]Tandis que Perpentach laissait retomber ses bras, un visage apparut derrière lui. Ou plutôt trois visages, trois nains sur les épaules les uns des autres. Le plus bas était tellement couvert de plaies et de cloques qu'il était difficile d'imaginer son visage. Celui au milieu était couvert de poux et de mouches, tandis que celui au-dessus, légèrement plus grand que les deux autres, avait une dague de théâtre profondément enfoncée dans son torse.[PARAGRAPH:1]Les nains du dessus et du dessous écartèrent les bras, puis plièrent les coudes et les poignets pour pointer dans la bonne direction. Le nain du centre parla. "Mon nom est Cafard et sous moi se trouve Cornichon et sur moi Pustule."[PARAGRAPH:1]La pile de nain tourna ensuite sur elle-même, remuant doucement jusqu'à faire à nouveau face au public. Bien qu'il n'y ait pas eu de changement tandis que l'empilement tournait le dos à la foule, le nain couvert de cloques occupait maintenant le centre de la pile, le nain le plus grand en bas et celui infesté de poux en haut.[PARAGRAPH:1]Cette fois, les nains en haut en bas eurent l'air surpris, les yeux écarquillés, les mains sur la bouche dans un simulacre de surprise. Le nain du center parla une fois de plus. "Mon nom est Cornichon, sous moi se trouve Pustule et au-dessus Cafard."[PARAGRAPH:1]La tour de nain tourna une fois de plus. Quand elle fit à nouveau face à la foule, l'ordre des nains avait changé. Le nain avec les mouches était au pied de la pile, la paume des mains couvrant ses yeux. La position du centre était occupée par le nain à la dague de théâtre, ses mains couvrant ses oreilles. Au sommet se trouvait le nain vérolé, une main en travers de la bouche. Le nain du centre parla encore. "Et mon nom est Pustule, sous moi se tient Cafard et sur moi Cornichon."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Maintenant vous savez," énonca Perpentach, comme s'il venait d'apprendre à un enfant à compter jusqu'à dix. "Quand vous construisez des cages d'escaliers, souvenez-vous seulement Cafard, Cornichon et Pustule."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Hmm... D'accord" répondit Faro. Il semblait presque convaincu en le disant.[PARAGRAPH:1]Perpentach se pinça le nez, comme pour éviter un éternuement. "Excusez moi," glapit-il du nez, puis décolla en éternuant avec aplomb. En atterrissant, il retira un mouchoir de son derrière. Tandis qu'il tirait, un autre mouchoir sortit, accroché au premier. Puis un autre, d'une couleur différente. Perpentach tira la ligne de mouchoirs toujorus plus grande jusqu'à son visage, et s'essuya le nez.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Il semble que j'ai pris un peu froid. Mon nez n'arrête pas de s'agiter. Votre nez s'agite-t-il, Faro ?"[PARAGRAPH:1]"Parfois, votre Augu..."[PARAGRAPH:1]Perpentach s'avança de quelques pas en triomphant joyeusement, son satin léopard scintillant d'une lumière sinistre. "Hé bien, si votre nez s'agite et vos pieds sentent, vous devez être conçu sans desus-dessous." Faro tressaillit d'horreur s'agrippa le visage. Au centre, l'emplacement de son nez disparu, il y avait un gros orteil. Remuant dans ses chaussures, un nez sentit son nouvel environnement avec une nouvelle et horrible curiosité.[PARAGRAPH:1]Essom méditait sur ce qu'elle avait vu. Dans un pays où seul le Maître pouvait entonner le chant de la destinée, tous les autres étaient des esclaves.

TEXT.Italian: Come si è arrivato a questo? Un giorno il villaggio di Essom stava sul confine delle terre Elohim con quelle adiacenti Balseraph, la sua popolazione tollerava allegramente le bizzarie di quella nazione turbolenta. Il giorno dopo il villaggio era nei territori Balseraph e la sua popolazione fu ridotta in schiavitù. Sorprendentemente, accettarono questa situazione senza ribattere, come se fosse la transizione più naturale al mondo.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Alzati in piedi, pigro zerbinotto, sta arrivando" Faro ringhiò.[PARAGRAPH:1]Ieri una tale affermazione sarebbe stata seguita dal suono di una frusta, e il fiume si sarebbe macchiato di sangue, ma, per oggi almeno, era stato dato un giorno libero agli schiavi, cosi da poter formare una folla di facce grate, tutte che accoglievano gradevolmente Perpentach, la Blasfemia Incarnata.[PARAGRAPH:1]Il principe pagliaccio arrivò vestito con un'abito rosso con bottoni neri e con nappe e finiture dorate, il tipo di vestito che usavano i portieri durante gli avvenimenti ufficiali di stato. L'orchestra iniziò a suonare l'inno nazionale Balseraph, La Danza del Cervo e dell'Anatra.[PARAGRAPH:1]"No! No! No! No! No!" Perpentach strillò. "State sbagliando tutto. Tu al violino, vai a suonare l'arpa. E tu, si, tu, con la tromba e il naso grande, prendi i timpani. E dite al coro di scambiarsi con l'ottavino, dato che ci siete".[PARAGRAPH:1]Essom guardava il caos generato mentre i musicisti si scambiavano di posto, cercando disperatamente uno strumento col quale avevano almeno un minimo di esperienza. Venì in mente ad Essom che Perpentach aveva la voce più ridicola che avesse mai sentito, una cosa stridula e senza sostanza. Eppure, tale era il suo carisma, che nessuno sentiva mai la voce ma bensì la minaccia dietro di essa.[PARAGRAPH:1]"E un du tre, e al vostro tempo."[PARAGRAPH:1]Il miscuglio risultante mancava di ritmo, melodia e talento, ma era compensato da un'entusiasmo nato dalla paura. Mentre le note discordanti si incastravano tra di loro con la stessa eleganza di uno scontro tra carrozze, Perpentach oscillava da un lato all'altro, muovendo il polso di qua e di la in sintonia con un suono di tromba esagerato o con uno scontro di piatti inapropriato. Il tempo cambiava in maniera selvaggia, alcuni musicisti finivano prima, mentre altri erano impegnati in assoli prolungati. Un coro a cappella garreggiava con la voce solista, e i testi andavano un pò meglio; almeno la metà dei coristi iniziò cantando l'inno nazionale della scorsa settimana, Due Violini e uno strattone alla vigilia del solstizio.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Eccellente! Eccellente! Non è molto meglio di quando non suoni la musica che viene preparata per te? Ora, dove sono le mie colombe?"[PARAGRAPH:1]"Colombe, Sire?" chiese Captain Faro[PARAGRAPH:1]"Colombe. Per annunciare la mia presenza naturalmente!" Perpentach sospirò. "Se vuoi qualcosa fatta bene, devi fartela da solo". Essom non aveva visto il principe cambiarsi i vestiti, ma ora Perpentach era vestito con un'abito nero e un cappello alto. Con uno squillo, l'araldo del caos estese il suo braccio sinistro e uno sciame di locuste usci dalla punta delle sue dita. Si ammassarono formando due colombe che poi volarono in mezzo alla folla.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Mi scuso per la mancanza di attrezzature, sire. Non succederà più." Captain Faro disse in maniera rispettosa, ma Essom aveva già visto quella faccia. Domani la frusta sarebbe stata peggiore.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Dico, Capitano, questo caldo ti fa sudare e puzzare i piedi?"[PARAGRAPH:1]La mancanza di logica stordì Faro che rispose balbettando in maniera affermativa.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Bene, allora dovremmo fare qualcosa al riguardo". E Perpentach prese un piccolo mazzo di fiori dall'occhiello del pigiama di seta di cui era al momento vestito. Staccando i petali dai fiori, li lasciava andare facendoli cullare dal vento.[PARAGRAPH:1]Da qualche parte nella folla una voce urlò "Lei mi ama." Con il petalo successivo, "Lei non mi ama." Presto l'intera folla stava dichiarando un'affetto imperterituro e un rimorso insostenibile con ogni petalo, fino a quando, con l'ultimo petalo "Lei non mi ama", i petali danzavano nell'aria per coprire il sole e oscurare la terra sottostante.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Ora mostrami il piano."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Certamente, Sire."[PARAGRAPH:1]"E smettila di chiamarmi Sire. Suona così formale. Da ora in poi devi chiamarmi l'Augurio più caritatevole di generosità e virtù."[PARAGRAPH:1]Captain Faro annuì e mostrò a Perpentach la via per la struttura. Tre pilastri stavano nel deserto, ognuno un monumento al sangue e al dolore degli schiavi Elohim. Marmo intagliato, con incisioni di rane e rospi che muoiono in una pioggia di fuoco, giacevano scartate al lato, pezzi di un puzzle che non avevano un posto.[PARAGRAPH:1]"In tutta onestà, Si... Più caritatevole augurio di... er... I nostri architetti non capiscono come vi aspettiate che tutte le scale salgano continuamente".[PARAGRAPH:1]"Davvero." Perpentach, ora vestito con una veste dorata che lo copriva dalla testa ai piedi, allungò le braccia. "Non possiamo averlo. Dopotutto, Non posso aspettarmi di avere dei servi che vivono sotto le scale se non ho le scale in primo luogo. Permettimi di dimostrare."[PARAGRAPH:1]Quando Perpentach abbassò le braccia, una figura apparì dietro di loro. O piuttosto tre figure, tre nani che stavano uno sopra l'altro. Quello più in basso aveva così tante piaghe e bolle che era difficile vedere il suo viso. Quello centrale era coperto di pidocchi e mosche, mentre quello in alto, che era un pò più alto degli altri, aveva un pugnale da palcoscenico immerso saldamente nel petto.[PARAGRAPH:1]I nani in alto e in basso alla pila allungarono le braccia, piegando i loro gomiti e mani per formare degli angoli retti. Il nano centrale disse. "Il mio nome è Weevil e sotto di me c'è Pickle e sopra di me c'è Hyde."[PARAGRAPH:1]La torre di nani poi ruotò sul posto lentamente fino a quando non erano di nuovo di fronte il pubblico. Sebbene non ci fossero stati cambiamenti apparenti nella torre mentre davano la schiena al pubblico, ora il nano con le bolle era al centro, con il nano alto in basso e il nano infestato dai pidocchi in cima alla torre.[PARAGRAPH:1]Questa volta, i nani in alto e in basso fecero facce sorprese, spalancando gli occhi, e coprendosi la bocca con le mani fingendo stupore. Il nano centrale disse un'altra volta. "Il mio nome è Pickle, sotto di me c'è Hyde e sopra di me c'è Weevil."[PARAGRAPH:1]La torre ruotò un'altra volta. Quando fronteggio il pubblico di nuovo, la posizione dei nani era cambiata. Il nano con le mosche era in basso, con le mani che coprivano gli occhi. La posizione centrale era occupata dal nano con il pugnale finto, con le mani che tappavano le orecchie. In alto c'era il nano butterato, con una mano che gli tappava la bocca. Il nano centrale disse di nuovo. "E il mio nome è Hyde, sotto di me c'è Weevil e sopra di me c'è Pickle."[PARAGRAPH:1]"E così il gioco è fatto," dichiarò Perpentach, come se avesse appena insegnato a un bambino a contare fino a dieci "Quando costruite le mie scale ricordatevi semplicemente di Weevil, Pickle e Hyde."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Erm... Certo" rispose Faro. Sembrava quasi che ci credesse.[PARAGRAPH:1]Perpentach si prese il naso, come per bloccare uno starnuto. "Mi scuso," disse con voce nasale, per poi starnutire con disinvoltura. Abbassandosi, prese un fazzoletto dal suo sedere. Mentre stava tirando, un'altro fazzoletto uscì, legato al primo, e poi un'altro ancora, di colore diverso dagli altri. Perpentach tiro la corda di fazzoletti sino alla sua faccia e si soffiò il naso.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Sembra che abbia preso un pò di freddo. Il mio naso non vuole smettere di colare. Cola anche il vostro naso, Faro?"[PARAGRAPH:1]"A volte, più carita..."[PARAGRAPH:1]Perpentach avanzò di qualche passo in un allegro trionfo, con la sua calzamaglia di raso che brillava di una funesta luminescenza". Bene, se il tuo naso cola e i tuoi piedi puzzano, devi essere stato costruito sottosopra". Cosi iniziò l'orrore di Faro afferrando la sua faccia. Al centro, dove un tempo c'era il suo naso, ora c'era un'alluce. Uscendo dai suoi sandali, un naso annusava ciò che lo circondava con curiosità inorridita.[PARAGRAPH:1]Essom riflette su cio che aveva visto. In una terra dove solo il direttore del circo può cantare la canzone del destino, chiunque è uno schiavo.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]How had it come to this? One day Essom's village stood on the border of the Elohim lands, adjoining Belseraphs, his people happily tolerating the bizarre antics of the troubadour nation. The next day the village was in Belseraphs territory and his people were slaves. More startling, they accepted it mindlessly, as if it were the most natural transition in the world.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Stand up straight, ye lazy popinjay, he's coming," Faro snarled.[PARAGRAPH:1]Yesterday such a remark would have been accompanied with the sting of the whip, and the river would have run with blood, but, for today at least, the slaves have been given the day off, so that they could form a crowd of grateful faces, all appreciatively welcoming Perpentech, the Blasphemy made Flesh.[PARAGRAPH:1]The clown prince arrived wearing a red suit with black buttons and golden tassels and trim, the kind that adorned doormen on official state occasions. The orchestra began to play the official Belseraphs national anthem, The Dance of the Deer and Duck.[PARAGRAPH:1]"No! No! No! No! No!" Perpentech squawked. "You're doing it all wrong. You on the fiddle, go and play the harp. And you, yes you, with the trumpet and the big nose, fetch the timpani. And tell the choir to swap with the piccolo section, whilst you're at it."[PARAGRAPH:1]Essom watched the havoc as musicians swapped places with one another, desperately trying to locate an instrument with which they might bear at least a passing acquaintance. It occurred to Essom that Perpentech had quite the most ridiculous voice that he had ever heard, a squeaky, reedy thing of no substance. And yet, such was his charisma, no-one ever heard the voice, just the threat behind it.[PARAGRAPH:1]"And a one-two-three, and in your own time."[PARAGRAPH:1]The resulting melange lacked rhythm, melody and talent, but made up for it with an enthusiasm born of fear. As discordant notes slid into one another with all the elegance of a coach crash, Perpentech swayed from side to side, flicking his wrist here and there in time with some overblown bugle cry or inappropriate cymbal clash. The tempo varied wildly, some musicians finishing early, whilst others were drawn into extended solos. A capella competed with soto voce, and the lyrics fared little better; at least half the choristers started by singing last week's National Anthem, Two fiddles and a tug by Solstice Eve.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Excellent! Excellent! Isn't out so much better when you don't play the music laid out for you? Now where are my doves?"[PARAGRAPH:1]"Doves, Sir?" asked Captain Faro[PARAGRAPH:1]"Doves. To announce my presence of course!" Perpentech sighed. "If you want something done, do it yourself." Essom had not seen the prince change his clothing, but now Perpentech was wearing a dark suit with a top hat. With a flourish, the harbinger of chaos swept out his left arm and a swarm of locusts emerged from his fingertips. They clustered together in the form of two doves and then flew into the crowd.[PARAGRAPH:1]"I apologise for the lack of facilities, sir. It shan't happen again." Captain Faro toadied, but Essom had seen that face before. Tomorrow the whip would be twice as harsh.[PARAGRAPH:1]"I say, Captain, do your feet sweat and stink in this heat?"[PARAGRAPH:1]The non-sequitur stunned Faro into stammering affirmative response.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Well we'll have to do something about that." And Perpentech seized a nosegay from the buttonhole of the silk pyjamas that current served as his raiment. Peeling the petals from the rose, he plucked them delicately letting them drift on the breeze.[PARAGRAPH:1]Somewhere in the crowd a voice cried "She Loves Me." With the next petal, "She Loves Me Not." Soon the entire multitude was declaring undying affection and remorseful regret with each petal, until, with the final "She Loves Me Not", the petals danced on the wind to smother the sun and darken the land below.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Now show me the project."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Of course, Sir."[PARAGRAPH:1]"And do stop calling me, Sir. It sounds so formal. From now on you must refer to me the Most Beneficent Augur of Munificence and Virtue."[PARAGRAPH:1]Captain Faro nodded and showed Perpentech the way to the structure. Three pillars stood in the desert, each a monument to the blood and pain of Elohim slaves. Carved marble masonry, engraved with etchings of frogs and toads dying in burning hail, lay discarded at the side, pieces of a jigsaw that don't fit in place.[PARAGRAPH:1]"In fairness, Si... Your most Beneficent Augur of... er... Our architects don't understand how you expect all the stairwells to be going up all the time."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Really." Perpentech, now dressed in a gold robe which covered him from head to foot, stretched out his arms. "We can't have that. After all, I can hardly be expected to have servants living below stairs if I don't have a staircase in the first place. Allow me to demonstrate."[PARAGRAPH:1]As Perpentech dropped his arms, a figure appeared behind them. Or rather three figures, three dwarves standing atop of each other. The one at the bottom had so many sores and boils it was hard to make out his visage. The central one was smothered in lice and flies, whereas the one at the top, who was slightly taller than the others, had a stage dagger plunged firmly in his chest.[PARAGRAPH:1]The dwarves at the top and the bottom of the stack stuck their arms out, bending their elbows and hands to point at right angles. The central dwarf spoke. "My name is Weevil and below me stands Pickle and above me stands Hyde."[PARAGRAPH:1]The tower of dwarves then rotated on the spot, slowly shuffling until they faced the audience once more. Although there had been no apparent change in the tower whilst their back was to the crowd, now the dwarf with the boils occupied the central spot, with the tall dwarf at the bottom and the lice-infested dwarf on the top of the stack.[PARAGRAPH:1]This time, the dwarves at the top and bottom of the stack made surprised faces, eyes wide open, hands covering their mouths in mock-astonishment. The central dwarf spoke once more. "My name is Pickle, below me stands Hyde and above me stands Weevil."[PARAGRAPH:1]The tower rotated once more. When it faced the audience again, the configuration of dwarves had changed. The dwarf with the flies was at the bottom of the stack, the palms of his hands covering his eyes. The central position was occupied by the dwarf with the stage dagger, his hands closed over his ears. At the top was the pockmarked dwarf, a hand cupped across his mouth. The central dwarf spoke again. "And my name is Hyde, below me stands Weevil and above me stands Pickle."[PARAGRAPH:1]"So there you have it," stated Perpentech, as if he had just taught a child how to count to ten "When you build my staircase just remember Weevil, Pickle and Hyde."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Erm... Right" replied Faro. He almost sounded like he believed it.[PARAGRAPH:1]Perpentech clutched his nose, as if to stifle a sneeze. "I do apologise," he squeaked nasally, and then broke wind with aplomb. Reaching down, he withdrew a handkerchief from his backside. As he pulled, another handkerchief came out, tied to the first, and then another, a different colour from the others. Perpentech pulled the string of ever increasing handkerchiefs up to his face and wiped his nose.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Just a little cold I seemed to have picked up. My nose just won't stop running. Does your nose run, Faro?"[PARAGRAPH:1]"Sometimes, Your Most Ben..."[PARAGRAPH:1]Perpentech stepped forwards in gleeful triumph, his satin leotard sparkling with baleful luminescence. "Well if your nose runs and your feet smell, you must be built upside-down." Faro started in his horror and seized his face. In the centre, where once his nose had been, there was a large toe. Poking through his sandals, a nose sniffed it's new surroundings with horrified curiosity.[PARAGRAPH:1]Essom mused on what he had seen. In a land where only the ringmaster can sing the song destiny intended, everyone else is a slave.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The 7th of Elembiuos, the Revelry, long have I waited for this day. Many would have complained about the remote post I have been assigned, a squalid little mountain village called Maledor, but it does have one advantage, it borders the Balseraph empire.[PARAGRAPH:1]The Revelry is celebrated in all cultures. Lanun ships moor themselves together into large floating islands where the wine and rum flow freely, the Hippus hold races and the Bannor are said to be able to come to their post up to 15 minutes late. But none of the festivals compare to the Balseraphs.[PARAGRAPH:1]The Balseraphs celebration lasts several days and foreigners often slip over into Balseraph cities to enjoy it. Disputes and wars are forgotten, most countries make it illegal to go, and most religions call it immoral. So foreigners have taken to wearing masks and elaborate costumes to keep from being recognized by fellow citizens and members of their local parish. Most importantly it keeps them from being recognized when they partake in the debauchery that they intended only to witness, but after an evening of vapors and vinum they are no doubt enjoying at a more personal level.[PARAGRAPH:1]In an hour I have seen more than in a lifetime watching village travelers. Goblins, elves, a hulking golem thundered by with a dwarf riding in a basket on its back. A jester with a puppet on his head followed the golem in mock pursuit. Actors on a stage with a black background enacted a tale where Esus was played by a man with half of his body in white, and half in black. When he turned to the right he was clearly visible in all his actions, but when he turned to the left he was invisible against the black of the stage. Various other actors played the roles of gods and men and were routinely outwitted by the disappearing god.[PARAGRAPH:1]If I was a wise man I would have stopped there, but behind the safety of my porcelain mask I dropped a few coins into the hands of a pigeon faced Imp and entered a tent draped in black and reds.[PARAGRAPH:1]Inside so many locusts hung on the canvas walls that little of the material could be seen. They buzzed and pushed against each other, filling the room with an odd clicking that made my skin crawl. Shorts chains hung from the ceiling like wind chimes, and they swayed and pulled to some unfelt breeze, often in opposite directions.[PARAGRAPH:1]The floor of the room was clear but for a straw mat, a small table and a withered man in drab brown robes.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Kneel" he said motioning toward the straw mat.[PARAGRAPH:1]"The sign promised prophetic visions, is that possible?" I knelt on the mat as I spoke, more nervous that I had wasted my money than that any harm would come to me. After seeing a small demon serving as doorman and making change a tent full of obedient bugs and disobedient chains wasn't that impressive.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Prophecy is easy, I would have only to show you leaving this tent, eating another meal or going to sleep in a bed to fulfill that obligation. There is a prophet on every corner, believing they serve some useful purpose by warning us of one overblown apocalypse or another. Death, plague, famine, war, these have always been, will always be, it takes no art to predict that."[PARAGRAPH:1]He picked up a thin gold needle from the table an inserted a tiny candle in its tapered end. He then felt along the base of my skull and down along my neck until he found the spot he wanted and inserted the needle deep into my skin.[PARAGRAPH:1]He continued to talk as he worked.[PARAGRAPH:1]"You will learn your future, you will see that which is and that which will be. You will leave here a new man."[PARAGRAPH:1]After inserting dozens of these golden needles he began to light the tiny candles within them. Slowly the wax melted, flowed down the hollow shaft and into my blood. I stared at the locusts shifting back and forth on the walls, listened to the chains hitting against each other above me but these senses drifted farther and farther away. I felt the weight of my body drop from me and I floated there in the tent in the haze of euphoria.[PARAGRAPH:1]Looking around the tent I noticed other people were here too. Strange grey people who were hooked to the chains that hung from the ceiling. A young woman writhed and pulled against her chain, stretching out from it before being pulled back. But most of the others, and there were dozens of others, simply floated around the tent staring at me with a look of sadness and concern.[PARAGRAPH:1]Such was the power of my euphoria that even the vision of these ghostly watchers didn't bother me. But when I looked down I saw my own body beneath me. Needles poked out of a dozen locations and continued to burn. The withered man moved around my body, making sure it remained kneeling and at rest. Then he looked up at where I floated above my body, looked into my drowsy eyes.[PARAGRAPH:1]This was the first moment I realized something was wrong. I tried to float back down to my body, flailing in the air but I didn't move. The withered man looked annoyed by my thrashing. He reached for an unused chain and then grabbed me out of the air and hooked me on it. My weightlessness was gone, instead the chain was my new world and all of my weight seemed to fall upon it.[PARAGRAPH:1]Held by the chain I could only watch as the withered man walked over to the wall and plucked one of the locusts off of it. Then he walked back to my kneeling body in the center of the room, opened my mouth and allowed the locust to crawl into it. I could vaguely feel the tiny scratches of locust feet on my tongue, the creature's hard shell pushing against the back of my mouth and down my throat, and then sudden and intense pain.[PARAGRAPH:1]I screamed, and in that moment the world was destroyed. Every person, place and object I had ever seen or imagined was gone and for a brief second I was alone in a world of perfect emptiness. Then everything was remade, piece by clumsy piece they came back together until creation was restored and I was back floating on the chain at the top of the tent.[PARAGRAPH:1]Beneath me my body stood talking to the withered man, but the expression on my face was not my own. It was a dark look without compassion. I could do nothing but watch as this new version of me picked up my porcelain mask, covered my face and left the tent.
